resources.string: Trail Sense uses location data in the background. It is used for sea level pressure calibration in weather monitoring and to provide more accurate sunset alerts. [View Privacy Policy](https://kylecorry.com/Trail-Sense/privacy_policy.html)

Trail Sense is for informational purposes only and the developers make no warranties concerning the accuracy of the information provided by the app, which may further be limited by the quality of your device's sensors and the current environmental conditions.

By using this app, you understand that the developers of Trail Sense cannot and do not assume responsibility for any personal injury, death, property damage, and other dangers associated with activities where you would use Trail Sense.

The developers of Trail Sense are not responsible for how you use the data provided, and what you do with it is done at your own risk. While it can be used in survival situations, you should not rely upon it, always have backup plans and gear, and use common sense. And definitely avoid using Trail Sense (and your phone in general) while driving or riding a bike.
Tips for improving sensor data accuracy

GPS: Go outside with an unobstructed view of the sky.
    %s of actual location
    %s of actual altitude
    %s satellites

Compass: Rotate device in a figure 8 pattern or in all directions and move away from metal.
Heat exhaustion/stroke risk. Be sure to stay hydrated, stay indoors or in shade, limit exercise, and watch for signs of heat exhaustion or stroke.
Hypothermia/frostbite risk. Be sure to stay hydrated, dress warm and limit exposed skin, and watch for signs of hypothermia or frostbite.
The temperature shown may be higher due to your phone\'s heat.
Estimate avalanche risks and the height of objects
Hold your phone vertically to measure inclination
Tap anywhere to set/unset inclination angle

"Calibration protocol: 
- Set this value to 1. 
- Measure the Trail Sense ruler value corresponding to one unit of a physical ruler. 
- Report the measured value here."
Rotate your phone in a figure 8 pattern or in all directions several times, click %s when finished.
Rotate your phone in a figure 8 pattern or in all directions several times, click %s when finished. \n \nThis alert can be disabled in the app settings.
Enter the current pressure at sea level in hPa
Corrects GPS altitude to above mean sea level
Using a known sea level pressure
Use the temperature in sea level pressure conversions
Use rapid pressure changes in sea level pressure conversions
Show closest beacons on the compass
Trail Sense ran into an error and will close. Please email the developer to get this issue fixed.
A how-to guide for using Trail Sense
%s and all its beacons will be deleted.
Only show readings when the altitude hasn\'t changed for at least an hour. Improves forecast reliability.
Tap sun or moon for position details
Keep track of items on hand
Use at your own risk.\n\nDo not use without a waterproof case and stay within a safe diving distance if possible.
Measure the height of a cliff or drop
Only use this tool when it is safe to do so, and be sure to check what is below the cliff to avoid injury. See the user guide for instructions.
Position solar panels for optimal power production
Place your phone on the face of the solar panel to begin.
Measure the distance from a lightning strike
Bring water to a rolling boil
The strobe feature contains flashing lights, which may be dangerous for some users.
A notification to sync your clock to GPS time
Set the time to %s when the notification arrives
Water will freeze if left out and rain may turn to snow

Decimal degrees (ex. 1.00, -2.00) Degrees decimal minutes (ex. 1°23.12\'N, 3°12.1\'W) Degrees minutes seconds (ex. 1°23\'12.1\"N, 3°12\"1.2\'W) UTM (ex. 03T 12345E 67890N) MGRS (ex. 27PXM 09601 05579)
Power saving mode on, some features may be disabled.
Changes you made will not be saved.
Backtrack is disabled in power saving mode
Disables some features to save power
Requires at least 4 satellites, improves accuracy
Forms a wavy sheet, clouds almost look two dimensional.
Covers the sky, but the sun can be seen through it.
Covers the sky, the sun can barely be seen.
Dark gray and covers the sky. It may be raining.
Covers the sky, objects don\'t cast shadows.
Rolling masses which form a sheet.
Dark gray, tall and anvil shape.

- Place beacons and navigate back to them

- Get your current location, altitude, and speed

- Retrace your steps with Backtrack (runs in the background when enabled)

- Get hyperlocal forecasts using your phone's barometer

- Does not use an Internet connection

- Be alerted of incoming storms

- Know when the sun/moon will rise and set

- Be alerted when the sun is going to set

- Locate the sun and moon on the compass

- Access tools to assist in any wilderness situation

- Signal using the flashlight or whistle

- Convert locations from a paper map to your phone

- Measure angles and determine the heights of objects

- Synchronize your clock without an Internet connection

- Take notes and keep track of items on hand

- Find dropped iron/steel objects
Learn how to use Trail Sense\'s features with the user guide. Available at the bottom of the Tools tab.\n\nMore guides will be coming soon.

- Trail Sense respects your privacy and location data never leaves your device

- Trail Sense will never require Internet permission

- View the [Privacy Policy](https://kylecorry.com/Trail-Sense/privacy_policy.html) (opens in your phone's browser)

- Some features of Trail Sense require access to your location

- Granting the location permission will enable the following features:

	- Navigating to beacons

	- Improved forecast accuracy (requires background location, not available on all devices)

	- Backtrack (requires background location)

	- Sun and moon times for your current location

- If you choose to not grant the location permission, you can manually enter a location in the Settings > GPS calibration menu in Trail Sense.

- After clicking continue, you will be prompted to grant the location and background location permissions. Denying those permissions will prevent Trail Sense from accessing your location, so a manual location entry is recommended.
Records cell signal at the waypoint. Does not use the Internet.
How to determine the beam distance of flashlights

Set the time of a high tide near you, preferably on the date of a new or full moon. This can be obtained online or via printed tide tables. The tides shown in Trail Sense may be off by up to two hours, which is good enough for reference but not to rely on.

The accuracy and battery usage of the pedometer is dependent on your device\'s manufacturer and the stride length entered. Try it out at home for a bit to verify battery drain and accuracy before using on the trail.
For the best accuracy, enable Backtrack and set the odometer source to pedometer in settings.
Enter the name of the map
How to determine distance travelled and arrival times
Map auto-calibrated, please verify its accuracy
On the radar compass and maps
The actual frequency may vary as some devices have background limits in place.
Small intervals (under 10 minutes) may cause excess battery drain
Camera permission denied, unable to turn on camera features. You can enable it in settings.
Creates a beacon for the last cell signal location
The pressure may differ from that of nearby stations
